facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 565-566 of 1963 were filed in Civil Appellate Jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 565-566 of 1963. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 31, 1962 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 940 and 1056 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeals were by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 31, 1962 of the Mysore High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 31, 1962 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 940 and 1056 of 1961. S. Pathak and M s. Rajinder Narain and Co. for the appellants.

facts.text: Judgment and order was in Writ Petitions Nos. 940 and 1056 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: the Mysore High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 940 and 1056 of 1961. S. Pathak and M s. Rajinder Narain and Co. for the appellants. Gopalakrishnan, for the respondent.

facts.text: Mysore University Act 23 of 1956 was enacted to reorganize the University of Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: The Mysore University Act 23 of 1956---hereinafter referred to as the Act--was enacted to provide for the reorganisation of the University of Mysore and other incidental matters.

facts.text: Academic Council framed clause 3(c) of the Regulations relating to the grant of B.V.Sc. degree.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the powers conferred by ss. 22, 23 and 43, Academic Council made Regulations relating to the grant of a degree for Bachelor of Veterinary Science.

facts.text: Clause 3(c) states: No candidate who fails four times shall be permitted to continue the course.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 3 c  of the Regulations is as follows No candidate who fails four times shall be permitted to continue the course.

facts.text: Mysore Veterinary College, Hebbal, Bangalore is affiliated to University of Mysore for B.V.Sc. course.

anchor.surface_text: The Mysore Veterinary College, Hebbal, Bangalore, is one of the colleges affiliated to the University of Mysore for training students for the degree course in Bachelor of Veterinary Science  B.V.Sc. .

facts.text: Gopala Gowda was admitted in 1958 as a student in the First Year Course in Mysore Veterinary College.

anchor.surface_text: Gopala Gowda--respondent in C.A. No. 565 of 1963--was admitted in the year 1958 as a student in the First Year Course in the Mysore Veterinary College.

facts.text: Gopala Gowda was declared unsuccessful in four successive First Year Course examinations.

anchor.surface_text: Gopala Gowda was declared unsuccessful in four successive First Year Course examinations.

facts.text: Controller of Examinations informed Gopala Gowda by letter dated August 2, 1961 that he lost right to continue under Regulation 3(c).

anchor.surface_text: The Controller of Examinations, Mysore University, then informed Gopala Gowda by letter dated August 2, 1961 that he had lost his right to continue studies for the Bachelor of Veterinary Science V.Sc.  course under Regulation 3 c

facts.text: Gopala Gowda filed writ petition in Mysore High Court to quash the order and permit appearance in exams.

anchor.surface_text: Gopala Gowda then presented a petition in the High Court of Mysore praying that, for reasons set out in his affidavit, the High Court do issue a writ quashing the order communicated by the Controller of Examinations in his letter dated August 2, 1961

facts.text: Bheemappa Reddy failed to satisfy examiners in four successive First Year Course examinations commencing from April 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The other respondent Bheemappa Reddy had also failed to satisfy the examiners in four successive First Year Course examinations commencing from April 1959,

facts.text: Controller intimated Bheemappa Reddy he would not be permitted to continue under Regulation 3(c).

anchor.surface_text: and on being intimated by the Controller of Examinations that he will not be permitted to continue his training for the Bachelor of Veterinary Science  B.V. Sc.  course under Regulation 3 c , he filed a similar writ petition in the High Court.

facts.text: Bheemappa Reddy filed similar writ petition in High Court.

anchor.surface_text: he filed a similar writ petition in the High Court.

facts.text: Mysore High Court held Regulation 3(c) beyond competence of Academic Council.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Mysore held that Regulation 3 c  of the Regulations governing the course of study leading to conferment of the degree of Bachelor of Veterinary Science of the Mysore University could not be said to subserve the purpose of maintaining the standards

facts.text: University of Mysore, Controller and Principal appealed to Supreme Court with special leave.

anchor.surface_text: With special leave. the University of Mysore, the Controller of Examinations and the Principal of the Mysore Veterinary College, have appealed.

facts.text: Since High Court decision on January 31, 1962, respondents were permitted to continue courses, passed second and third year exams, permitted for degree exam.

anchor.surface_text: We are informed at the Bar, however, that since the High Court decided. the case on January 31, 1962, the two respondents were permitted to continue their courses of study and they have appeared for the subsequent examinations and they were declared to have duly passed their second and third year examination

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals are therefore dismissed.

facts.text: Academic Council has powers under sections 22, 23 and 43 of Mysore University Act.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals raise the question whether the Academic Council of the Mysore University was competent in exercise of the powers conferred by ss. 22, 23 and 43 of the Mysore University Act 23 of 1956 to frame cl. 3 c  of the Regulations

facts.text: University did not apply for interim orders pending appeals.

anchor.surface_text: having regard to the fact that the respondents were permitted to continue their course of study, the University not having applied for any interim orders pending disposal of these appeals,

Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 31, 1962 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 940 and 1056 of 1961. S. Pathak and M s. Rajinder Narain and Co. for the appellants.
With special leave. the University of Mysore, the Controller of Examinations and the Principal of the Mysore Veterinary College, have appealed.

These appeals are filed with special leave, and in the exceptional circumstances of the case, we do not think we would be justified, merely because we disagree with the interpretation of the High Court of the relevant regulation,

These appeals raise the question whether the Academic Council of the Mysore University was competent in exercise of the powers conferred by ss. 22, 23 and 43 of the Mysore University Act 23 of 1956 to frame cl. 3 c  of the Regulations

concepts.interpretation: Confers on Academic Council control and general regulation of teaching, courses of studies to be pursued, and maintenance of standards, including power to frame regulations to weed out unfit students by barring continuation after four failures as a reasonable test of inaptitude.

concepts.unlisted_description: Powers of the Academic Council: control and general regulation of teaching, courses of studies, maintenance of standards, and other prescribed powers.

anchor.surface_text: s. 22 sets out the powers of the Academic Council. It provides The Academic Council shall, subject to the provisions of this Act, have the control and general regulation of teaching, courses of studies to be pursued, and maintenance of the standards thereof and shall exercise such other powers and perform such other duties as may be prescribed.

concepts.interpretation: Confers on Academic Council control and general regulation of teaching, courses of studies to be pursued, and maintenance of standards, including power to frame regulations to weed out unfit students by barring continuation after four failures as a reasonable test of inaptitude.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: University, but it does number and cannot be taken to mean that by reason only of the fact that a student has number attained the standard of knowled

concepts.unlisted_description: Powers of the Academic Council: control and general regulation of teaching, courses of studies, maintenance of standards, and other prescribed powers.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 23 other powers of the Academic Council are prescribed. Insofar as it is material, the section provides In particular and without prejudice to the generality of the powers specified in section 22, the Academic Council shall have, subject to the provisions of this Act, the following powers, namely  a  x x x x  b  x x x x  c  to make Regulations relating to courses, schemes of examinations and conditions on which students shall be admitted to the examinations, degrees, diplomas, certificates and other academic distinctions

concepts.interpretation: Authorizes Academic Council to make regulations relating to courses, schemes of examinations, and conditions for admission to examinations, which includes power to deny admission to students unfit after four failures.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: University, but it does number and cannot be taken to mean that by reason only of the fact that a student has number attained the standard of knowled

concepts.unlisted_description: Additional powers of Academic Council, including to make regulations on courses, examinations, and admission conditions.

anchor.surface_text: Section 43 of the Act sets out the scope of the Regulations. enacts Subject to the provisions of this Act, the Regulations may provide for the exercise of all or any of the powers, enumerated in sections 22 and 23 of this Act and for the following matters, namely the admission of students to the University the recognition of the examinations and degrees of other Universities as equivalent to the examinations and degrees of the University the University courses and examinations and the conditions on which students of the University and affiliated colleges

concepts.interpretation: Allows regulations to provide for conditions on which students shall be admitted to examinations, empowering regulation barring continuation after four failures.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: University, but it does number and cannot be taken to mean that by reason only of the fact that a student has number attained the standard of knowled

concepts.unlisted_description: Scope of regulations, including admission to examinations and conditions for degrees.

issues.text: whether the Academic Council of the Mysore University was competent in exercise of the powers conferred by ss. 22, 23 and 43 of the Mysore University Act 23 of 1956 to frame cl. 3 c of the Regulations relating to the grant of the degree for Bachelor of Veterinary Science (B.V.Sc.)

anchor.surface_text: These appeals raise the question whether the Academic Council of the Mysore University was companypetent in exercise of the powers companyferred by ss. 22, 23 and 43 of the Mysore University Act 23 of 1956 to frame cl. 3 c  of the Regulations

issues.text: whether, despite disagreement with the High Court's interpretation of the relevant regulation, the Supreme Court should make an effective order nullifying the respondents' examination results in exercise of discretion under Article 136

anchor.surface_text: These appeals are filed with special leave, and in the exceptional circumstances of the case, we do not think we would be justified, merely because we disagree with the interpretation of the High Court of the relevant regulation,

arguments.claim: Regulation 3(c) could not be said to subserve the purpose of maintaining the standards mentioned in s. 22 of the Mysore University Act and was beyond the competence of the Academic Council

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Mysore held that Regulation 3 c  of the Regulations governing the course of study leading to conferment of the degree of Bachelor of Veterinary Science of the Mysore University could not be said to subserve the purpose of maintaining the standards

court_response_anchor.surface_text: University, but it does number and cannot be taken to mean that by reason only of the fact that a student has number attained the standard of knowled

arguments.court_reasoning: Academic Council has power to control entire academic life and weed out unfit students under ss. 22, 23

arguments.claim: Under s. 22, Academic Council can prescribe minimum qualifications for admission and standards for degree but not power to prescribe condition barring continuation of studies after admission

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the High Court, under s. 22 of the Act the Academic Council could prescribe minimum qualifications for admission to a degree course in an affiliated college, and also could prescribe standards which qualify a candidate .for admission to the degree or academic distinction, but the Council had no

court_response_anchor.surface_text: University, but it does number and cannot be taken to mean that by reason only of the fact that a student has number attained the standard of knowled

arguments.court_reasoning: Admission does not divest Council of control; power extends to barring unfit students

arguments.claim: Power to frame regulations under ss. 22 and 23(c) does not include power to prevent admitted student from prosecuting studies; failure only leads to withholding degree

anchor.surface_text: Power to frame Regulations for maintenance of standards within the meaning of s. 22 and prescribing conditions on which a student shall be admitted to an examination within the meaning of s. 23 c did not, in the opinion. of the High Court, import power to make Regulation preventing a student admitted to a course from prosecuting his study, for the only consequence of failure in an examination is that the student does not qualify himself for admission to the degree

arguments.qualifiers: in the opinion of the High Court

court_response_anchor.surface_text: University, but it does number and cannot be taken to mean that by reason only of the fact that a student has number attained the standard of knowled

arguments.court_reasoning: Power to prescribe conditions for exams includes power to refuse admission to exams for unfit students

arguments.claim: Maintenance of standards under s. 22 refers only to undergoing course, minimum attendance, not barring student for failing to attain proficiency within period

anchor.surface_text: The expression maintenance of standards in the view of the High Court could only take in considerations such as undergoing a course of study and keeping a prescribed minimum attendance to an institution maintained or recognised by the University, but it does not and cannot be taken to mean that by reason only of the fact that a student has not attained the standard of knowledge or proficiency required for passing the examination within that period, he can be said to be for all times incapable of attaining that standard.

arguments.qualifiers: in the view of the High Court

court_response_anchor.surface_text: University, but it does number and cannot be taken to mean that by reason only of the fact that a student has number attained the standard of knowled

arguments.court_reasoning: No warrant for restricting maintenance of standards to attendance and length of course; includes directing discontinuation for inaptitude

arguments.claim: Power to maintain standards involves withholding degree if not attained, but not refusing permission to attain the standard

anchor.surface_text: The power to maintain certain standards before a degree or other academic distinction is conferred upon a person involves the power to withhold the conferment of that degree unless a person attains the necessary standard, but it cannot either in logic or in justice involve the power to refuse to permit a person to attain that standard.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: University, but it does number and cannot be taken to mean that by reason only of the fact that a student has number attained the standard of knowled

arguments.court_reasoning: Power to control standards includes weeding out unfit via reasonable tests like four failures

arguments.claim: Suitability should be checked at admission; once admitted, university opines student has capacity to attain standard by undergoing course

anchor.surface_text: That power can and should be exercised at the time of admission into the course of study if the University is of the opinion that the applicant for .admission into the course does not even possess the minimum suitability for taking that course of study. Once it admits him into the course of study, it must be held to have entertained the opinion that he does have the minimum suitability to take that course which means that he has the capacity by undergoing the course of study to attain the standard necessary for receiving the degree.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: University, but it does number and cannot be taken to mean that by reason only of the fact that a student has number attained the standard of knowled

arguments.court_reasoning: Control continues post-admission; supervening inaptitude can be addressed

arguments.claim: Academic Council under ss. 22, 23, 43 has power to frame Regulation 3(c) as it controls teaching, courses, standards, and conditions for exams, including barring unfit students after four failures

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the view expressed by the high Court. The Academic Council is invested with the power of controlling and generally regulating teaching,. courses of studies to be pursued. and maintenance of the standards thereof. and for those purposes the Academic Council is competent to make regulations. amongst others, relating to the courses, schemes of examination and conditions on which students shall be admitted to the examinations.

arguments.claim: Power to prescribe conditions for admission to examinations implies power to refuse/weed out students unfit after reasonable test like four failures to prevent lowering of standards

anchor.surface_text: Power to prescribe conditions, On which, a student may be admitted to the examinations, in our opinion, necessarily implies the power to refuse to admit a student in certain contingencies, for the power to admit to an examination implies the power to weed out students who have on the application of a reasonable test proved themselves to be unfit to continue the course or prosecute training in that course. ... failure by a student to qualify for promotion or degree in four examinations, is certainly a reasonable test of such inaptitude or supervening disability. If after securing admission to an institution imparting training for professional courses, a student may be held entitled to continue indefinitely to attend the institution without adequate application and to continue to offer himself for successive examinations, a lowering of academic standards would inevitably result.

arguments.qualifiers: in our judgment, in our opinion

arguments.claim: No warrant for restricting 'maintenance of standards' to minimum attendance, course length; includes refusing degree and directing discontinuation for lack of aptitude within reasonable time

anchor.surface_text: Power to maintain standards in the course of studies. in our judgment, confers authority not merely to prescribe minimum qualifications for admission, courses of study, and minimum attendance at an institution which may qualify the student for admission to the examination, but also authority to refuse to grant a degree... and to direct that a student who is proved not to have the ability or the aptitude to complete the course within a reasonable time to discontinue the course. There is no warrant for restricting the expression maintenance of the standards only to matters such as minimum attendance, length of the course and prescription of minimum academic attainments.

arguments.claim: Despite disagreeing with High Court on merits, appeals dismissed without nullifying respondents' exam results due to no interim orders, students progressed, exceptional circumstances under Art. 136

anchor.surface_text: We are informed at the Bar, however, that since the High Court decided. the case on January 31, 1962, the two respondents were permitted to continue their courses of study and they have appeared for the subsequent examinations and they were declared to have duly passed their second and third year examination... Even though, the view taken by the High Court was erroneous, we do not think. having regard to the fact that the respondents were permitted to continue their course of study, the University not having applied for any interim orders pending disposal of these appeals, that any order should be passed in these appeals so as to deprive the respondents of the training they have received. These appeals are filed with special leave, and in the exceptional circumstances of the case, we do not think we would be justified, merely because we disagree with the interpretation of the High Court of the relevant regulation, in making an effective order against the respondents so as to nullify the results declared by the University concerning them in respect of the second and third year examinations.

arguments.qualifiers: we do not think we would be justified

holdings.text: The Academic Council of the Mysore University was competent in exercise of the powers conferred by ss. 22, 23 and 43 of the Mysore University Act 23 of 1956 to frame cl. 3(c) of the Regulations relating to the grant of the degree for Bachelor of Veterinary Science (B.V.Sc.).

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the view expressed by the high Court. The Academic Council is invested with the power of controlling and generally regulating teaching,. courses of studies to be pursued. and maintenance of the standards thereof. and for those purposes the Academic Council is competent to make regulations. amongst others, relating to the courses, schemes of examination and conditions on which students shall be admitted to the examinations.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Academic Council has control over teaching, courses, standards under s.22; power to make regulations on exams and admission conditions under s.23(c) and s.43 includes authority to bar continuation after four failures as reasonable test of inaptitude to prevent lowering standards.

holdings.text: Power to prescribe conditions on which students shall be admitted to examinations necessarily implies power to refuse admission to unfit students after reasonable test like four successive failures.

anchor.surface_text: Power to prescribe conditions, On which, a student may be admitted to the examinations, in our opinion, necessarily implies the power to refuse to admit a student in certain contingencies, for the power to admit to an examination implies the power to weed out students who have on the application of a reasonable test proved themselves to be unfit to continue the course or prosecute training in that course.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Implied power from statutory authority to regulate exams and standards; four failures indicates inaptitude; indefinite continuation would lower standards.

holdings.text: Maintenance of standards under s.22 includes authority to direct discontinuation of course for students lacking aptitude after reasonable time, not limited to attendance or course length.

anchor.surface_text: Power to maintain standards in the course of studies. in our judgment, confers authority not merely to prescribe minimum qualifications for admission, courses of study, and minimum attendance at an institution which may qualify the student for admission to the examination, but also authority to refuse to grant a degree...

holdings.reasoning_summary: No textual warrant for narrow interpretation; full control over academic life post-admission includes weeding out unfit to uphold standards.

holdings.text: The High Court erred in holding that Regulation 3(c) was beyond competence of Academic Council.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore in error in holding that the Academic Council had no power to prescribe Regulation 3 c .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects High Court's narrow view of ss.22,23; affirms broad regulatory powers.

holdings.text: Even though High Court's view was erroneous, appeals dismissed without nullifying respondents' exam results due to exceptional circumstances, lack of interim stay, and discretion under Art.136.

anchor.surface_text: We are informed at the Bar, however, that since the High Court decided. the case on January 31, 1962, the two respondents were permitted to continue their courses of study and they have appeared for the subsequent examinations and they were declared to have duly passed their second and third year examination... The appeals are therefore dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Special leave appeals; no interim orders sought; respondents progressed; unjust to deprive training now.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals are filed with special leave, and in the exceptional circumstances of the case, we do number think we would be justified, merely because we disagree with the interpretation of the High Court of the relevant regulation, in making an effective order against the respondents so as to nullify the results declared by the University companycerning them in respect of the second and third year examinations. The appeals are therefore dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals dismissed; no order passed so as to deprive the respondents of the training they have received or nullify the results declared by the University concerning them in respect of the second and third year examinations

anchor.surface_text: Power to prescribe conditions, On which, a student may be admitted to the examinations, in our opinion, necessarily implies the power to refuse to admit a student in certain contingencies, for the power to admit to an examination implies the power to weed out students who have on the application of a reasonable test proved themselves to be unfit to continue the course or prosecute training in that course.

These appeals are filed with special leave, and in the exceptional circumstances of the case, we do number think we would be justified, merely because we disagree with the interpretation of the High Court of the relevant regulation, in making an effective order against the respondents so as to nullify the results declared by the University companycerning them in respect of the second and third year examinations. The appeals are therefore dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: We are informed at the Bar, however, that since the High Court decided. the case on January 31, 1962, the two respondents were permitted to continue their courses of study and they have appeared for the subsequent examinations and they were declared to have duly passed their second and third year examination... The appeals are therefore dismissed.
